Sentence: Right-to-left shunts often result in cyanosis, a bluish tint to the skin due to insufficient oxygen .
Label: Explanation

Sentence: Left-to-right shunts may not always cause visible symptoms, as the body can sometimes compensate for the extra oxygen .
Label: Explanation

Sentence: Right-to-left shunts are more common in conditions like patent ductus arteriosus, while left-to-right shunts can be seen in conditions like tetralogy of Fallot .
Label: Definition

Sentence: In contrast, right-to-left shunts reduce the amount of oxygen reaching the systemic circulation, while left-to-right shunts increase it .
Label: Contrast

Sentence: Understanding these effects is crucial for diagnosing and treating cardiovascular conditions .
Label: Purpose

Sentence: Identifying the specific type of shunt is essential for determining the appropriate treatment strategy .
Label: Clarification

Sentence: In summary, right-to-left shunts decrease oxygenation, while left-to-right shunts increase it, both affecting heart function .
Label: Summary
